awd_titl_txt: Neurocognitive underpinnings of dyslexia and dyscalculia
awd_abstract_narration:
Difficulties in math and reading prevent many students from succeeding in STEM education which demands both math and reading skills.  Dyslexia is the most common type of learning disability affecting reading proficiency but many students with dyslexia also exhibit dyscalculia, or math disability. To date, little research has sought to understand the extent of the neurobiological connections between dyslexia and dyscalculia.  

This proposal will explore the cognitive underpinnings of dyscalculia observed in children with dyslexia. Dyslexia and dyscalculia have traditionally been studied as separate development difficulties but this project will seek to determine whether math difficulties that exist in children with dyslexia are similar or different from the math difficulties that exist in children with dyscalculia only.  The investigators will recruit 150 children aged 10-12 and screen them for dyslexia, dyscalculia, and both dyslexia and dyscalculia. A battery of behavioral measures in both reading and math are planned along with neuroimaging (fMRI) data collection methods.   

This project is supported by NSF's EHR Core Research (ECR) program. The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field. Investments are made in critical areas that are essential, broad and enduring: STEM learning and STEM learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development. The program supports the accumulation of robust evidence to inform efforts to understand, build theory to explain, and suggest intervention and innovations to address persistent challenges in STEM interest, education, learning and participation.

por.por_cntn:
Reading and math skills are foundational for learning throughout schooling and into adulthood. Many students struggle with reading, math, or both. Difficulties in reading or math also impact the ability to learn in STEM - science, technology, engineering, and math - topics. During early elementary school, students are building foundational skills in reading and math. By late elementary school, classroom activities shift to using these skills to learn new knowledge. This shift was coined in the field of reading as ‘learning to read’ to ‘reading to learn’ by renowned education researcher Jeanne Chall. Although reading and math difficulties have been studied before, most studies have often focused on one difficulty at a time. Less is known about how reading and math difficulties may co-occur and what the brain basis of this common association may be. We focused on students in late elementary school (grades 5-6), who recently experienced this shift from learning foundational skills to applying them for new knowledge and skills. We recruited 250 students across a wide range of abilities in reading and math. Each student completed psychoeducational assessments of cognition, reading, and math skills, as well as surveys about motivation and anxiety for reading and math. Students also completed a brain imaging session that collected data on the brain’s structure and function while completing reading and math tasks. We developed experimental tasks for the neuroimaging component as well as surveys of math motivation and reading anxiety (most measures capture math anxiety or reading motivation).

Preliminary results offered insights on the frequency of reading difficulty/disability (RD) and math difficulty/disability (MD). Of the children who were enrolled carrying a history of RD, 75% were confirmed as having current RD using psychoeducational assessments. From that sample, 65% qualified as comorbid with MD, and only 20% of students were impacted by RD only with no difficulties in math. Interestingly, very few students were enrolled with MD only, so we could not study potential co-occurrence with RD in this group. These findings suggest that difficulties in math are rarely isolated and occur most often in association with reading difficulties. This insight highlights a potential need to more closely examine both reading and math skills, when students are assessed for one or the other. It is possible that students have a shared underlying difficulty impacting both reading and math, unique challenges that co-occur, or the consequences of a reading difficulty are severe enough to impact math performance (for example).

In addition, we examined socio-emotional characteristics associated with reading and math. We found several insights: (1) across the range of skills for reading and math, students with higher competence had higher motivation and lower anxiety, on average; (2) children with more anxiety in one domain (reading or math) tended to have more anxiety in the other domain, and the same was found for motivation; (3) reading socio-emotional characteristics predict math competence, but math socio-emotional characteristics did not predict reading skills; and (4) math motivation was a stronger predictor of math competence than math anxiety. These results help us deepen the appreciation of socio-emotional characteristics of students as they relate to reading and math.

There are several educational and clinical implications of this research. We offer novel insights on the co-occurrence of reading and math difficulties, highlighting elevated rates of potentially under-identified difficulty. We created surveys of reading anxiety and math motivation that are publically available to match existing surveys of reading motivation and math anxiety, broadening the range of tools for measuring socio-emotional competencies. These outcomes elevate our understanding of the relation between reading and math and can empower educators and clinicians to improve identification and intervention practices for struggling learners.
